image.altText: A computerised image of Keith Lees with a beard.

props.synopsis: For nearly 27 years, the family of Meaghan Rose have been trying to prove she was murdered. Now, the ABC can reveal fresh details about her suspected killer.

title.children: Police believe a cold case murder suspect could be hiding 'anywhere in Australia'. They want your help to find him

image.altText: Protesters holding signs protesting against Woodside's Burrup Hub development.

props.synopsis: Climate activists want Woodside leaders to feel some consequence for what they say the company is inflicting on the world, but investor activists have a slightly different point of view.

title.children: An unlikely marriage brought down the climate plan of Australia's biggest oil and gas company. It's already on the rocks

image.altText: A young woman holds up a sign that says  please stop killing us

props.synopsis: Advocacy groups are demanding the government declare violence against women a national emergency after the alleged killing of three women by men known to them.

title.children: Protests against 'epidemic of male violence' kick off around country

image.altText: A police car parked near small aircraft.

props.synopsis: A pilot and passenger have died after a light aircraft crash at Mount Beauty airport in Victoria's east.

title.children: Two people dead after aircraft crash near Falls Creek

image.altText: She stands by a lake and looks concerned

props.synopsis: Debate around the proposed South Coast Marine Park has sparked a swell of negative attitudes towards Indigenous people, with local leaders urged to do more to call it out.

title.children: Leaders urged to call out racism, false claims in heated WA marine park debate

image.altText: A man sitting on a chair with trees behind him looking at the camera

props.synopsis: He was a man of many faces but few people knew of the forces that formed his ebullient personality.

title.children: Late TV chef Ian Parmenter revealed childhood bullying behind his madcap persona in final interview

image.altText: A woman holding a framed photo of a young man

props.synopsis: Pilbara mother Kristie Grabenhofer says her son, who took his life at 21, would still be alive if he'd been able to access the mental health care he needed.

title.children: 'Our son should still be here': Grieving mum demands better mental health services

image.altText: an aerial view of bright blue channels of water in the outback

props.synopsis: In Australia's remote north, channels that usually lay dusty and dormant are alight with green and "bringing everything back to life".

title.children: On the verge of two deserts, this little-known western channel country has come alive

image.altText: ding xuan poses for pictures

props.synopsis: As young people in China feel the squeeze of cost of living and social pressures, many are looking to the country's forgotten older cities where they can buy a home for the price of rent in a megacity and pursue the kind of life they want, not one forced upon them.

title.children: Xuan bought a $6,000 apartment in an old Chinese city so she could 'lie flat' and escape the rat race

image.altText: Ollie Hollands tackled by Zach Tuohy during Cats-Blues AFL match.

props.synopsis: Undefeated Geelong meets Carlton in a blockbuster clash, after the Crows earn a big win over the Kangaroos. Later, Fremantle hosts the Western Bulldogs. Follow our live blog.

title.children: Fast and furious at the MCG as Cats get the early jump on the Blues

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: QT: Geelong leads Carlton by 12 points
FT: Crows score big win over struggling Kangaroos

image.altText: NRL player Adam Reynolds about to kick a football which is falling to his feet, during a match

props.synopsis: Big names return for the Brisbane Broncos as they travel to Campbelltown, the spiritual home of the old Magpies, to battle the Wests Tigers. Follow live.

title.children: Reynolds and Haas return for Broncos against Wests Tigers

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: No late changes for Wests Tigers or Brisbane
Brisbane welcome back big names for Tigers clash
Smashed windows and bloody hearts: The last flight of the Western Suburbs Magpies

image.altText: Two images of women, one of them is generated by AI.

props.synopsis: Experts have warned that generative artificial intelligence is now capable of producing images of faces that appear more human than actual faces. So what does this mean for the future of the internet?

title.children: Can you spot which of these faces is generated by AI? Probably not — here's why

image.altText: A middle-aged blonde woman through the trees in her backyard.

props.synopsis: Julieanne Hilbers spends much of her life with her hands in the dirt, planting native shrubs in her garden, so she thinks it makes sense for her body to be turned into human compost after she dies.

title.children: Julieanne wants human composting to be legalised so she can return to the earth when she dies

image.altText: A graphic of a skull and crossbones against a backdrop of newspapers clippings.

props.synopsis: American journalist Deborah Vankin can still recall sitting down one day to read her own obituary. Her search to uncover who was behind it, unearthed a cottage industry of spammy websites run by 'obit pirates'.

title.children: 'People with malicious intent, they are capitalising on this': Is this the world's weirdest scam?

image.altText: A woman with purple hair, sitting in a wheelchair, in front of her brick house.

props.synopsis: A building design standard to ensure all new houses are accessible for people with disability could future-proof the nation's housing stock. But not every state is onboard.

title.children: The rush is on to build new homes, but will they be suitable for our ageing population?

image.altText: A crowd of mostly women gather outside, holding signs, one reads ENOUGH IS ENOUGH in red text

props.synopsis: Australians will march this weekend in rallies around the country calling for an end to violence against women. Haven't we marched enough? asks Virginia Trioli.

title.children: How long will women be marching in the street asking not to be murdered?

image.altText: A man in a suit standing outside links arms with a woman and gazes at her, while she smiles at the camera

props.synopsis: In a statement, Buckingham Palace says the King's doctors are "pleased with his progress", 12 weeks after it revealed the monarch's diagnosis.

title.children: King Charles to resume public duties, but cancer fight not over

image.altText: A smiling, young Asian woman walking towards the camera, with large artworks on the wall behind her.

props.synopsis: In large-scale charcoal drawings filled with movement, details and pop-art references, artist Anna Park explores what it is to live in an age consumed by social media that both warps and shapes our reality.

title.children: Life in the digital age rendered in stark black and white by New York-based artist

image.altText: A man poses in front of a service station with Mt Fuji in the background as someone takes a photo

props.synopsis: A huge black barrier to block Mount Fuji from view will be installed in a popular photo spot by Japanese authorities exasperated by crowds of badly behaved foreign tourists.

title.children: Japanese town to block Mount Fuji view from troublesome tourists

image.altText: a ripped bodybuilder flexes his chest

props.synopsis: While only doctors can prescribe it in Australia, bodybuilders have begun experimenting with Ozempic.

title.children: 'Revolutionary' weight loss drug tempts bodybuilders, raises alarm for eating disorders

image.altText: A woman in a clothing shop sorts through garments hanging from a wall.

props.synopsis: A regional Victorian initiative dedicated to providing new clothing to vulnerable people is struggling to keep up with demand as donations from its retail partners decrease.

title.children: Clothing donations threadbare as retailers tighten belts amid rising demand

props.synopsis: A debate that has largely been framed in terms of freedom of speech has become conflated with a whole range of issues that now challenge us: from social cohesion, to terrorism, to domestic violence.

title.children: From domestic violence to terrorism and war, social media is a thread that connects all the issues that now challenge us

image.altText: A middle-aged white man in a suit sits in a courtroom, looking down with a serious expression

props.synopsis: Elijah McClain, who had been forcibly restrained after police stopped him as he was walking home, went into cardiac arrest on the way to the hospital and died three days later.

title.children: US paramedic who injected Elijah McClain with ketamine before his death avoids prison

image.altText: An aerial shot of a man in a brown suit stacking rifles on top of each other on a table.

props.synopsis: Police officers will soon be able to access near real-time information on firearms and who owns them after the federal government committed hundreds of millions of dollars to implement a national firearms register.

title.children: The Wieambilla attack reignited calls for a national firearms register. $160 million will see it eventuate

image.altText: Police standing in a street with cones on the floor.

props.synopsis: Victoria Police is investigating after a man was found shot dead in a vehicle in Hampton Park.

title.children: Homicide detectives investigate deadly drive-by shooting in Melbourne's south-east

image.altText: A palm tree and other green foliage with buildings, a bay and headland in the background.

props.synopsis: Pacific Island nations are looking abroad for workers, and taking control of labour mobility schemes at home, as they look to address labour shortages hitting employers. But experts say it's too early to say whether they're succeeding.

title.children: Vanuatu is importing its own foreign workers as labourers move to Australia and NZ for higher pay

image.altText: Four CCTV panels of a woman walkign through the door of a shop in a coat carrying a bag

props.synopsis: Journalist Jill Dando was at the height of her career and preparing for a fast-approaching wedding when she was murdered in 1999. Now 25 years later, there are still unanswered questions.

title.children: One of the BBC's most popular presenters was 'assassinated on her doorstep in broad daylight' more than two decades ago

image.altText: Daria Saville looks frustrated sitting on her bench

props.synopsis: Daria Saville's luck finally runs out at the Madrid Open as Australia's sole woman representative in the big clay-court event is knocked out  for a second time in four days.

title.children: Daria Saville knocked out of Madrid Open for the second time in four days

image.altText: A baker is photographed through a bakery window as he bakes baguettes

props.synopsis: Competing baguettes in the annual bread-making competition were evaluated for taste, look, texture, airiness and the quality of the baking.

title.children: Paris crowns a new king of the crusty, long bread in its annual 'Grand Prix de la baguette'

image.altText: Close up of Andrew Tate wearing a tweed blazer

props.synopsis: The Bucharest Tribunal has ruled the prosecutors' case file against online influencer Andrew Tate met the legal criteria, but did not set a date for the trial to begin.

title.children: Andrew Tate's trial on charges of rape and human trafficking can start, a Romanian court rules

image.altText: A composite images of book covers: Caledonian Road, Martyr, The Spoiled Heart, White Cockatoo Flowers, Bullet Paper Rock

props.synopsis: Get lost in these new books — including a posthumous release from a beloved Australian writer, an insouciant short story collection and a thumping evisceration of British culture.

title.children: The best new books our avid readers and critics read in April
